subject: Re: [junit] Re: where lives your junit stuff
msgSnippet: JUnit is not installed with Maven in the traditional sense. Instead, Maven automatically downloads the JUnit jars (and other jars that your application
messageBody:
JUnit is not "installed" with Maven in the traditional sense. Instead,
Maven automatically downloads the JUnit jars (and other jars that your
application requires, as declared via <dependencies> in the pom.xml
file) when you run Maven.

You might want to check out the free pdf "Better Builds with Maven" to
get a better sense for what Maven is and how it works etc. A lot of us
are big fans of the tool, but there are also many people who dislike
it for various reasons.

Wayne

>> Java-RTs und SDKs I usually install on

>> %program files%\java
>> \j2rt1.4

>> For the default java runtime I use 1.6 and set it
>> to JAVA_HOME=%program files%\java\jdk1.6
>>
>> For libraries I usually use maven. So its very
>> simple to set references to any library. I set it
>> to PATH=%PATH%,C:\mvnrepos
>>
>> In special cases I also use a separate lib
>> directory. Its a remainder of the time before I
>> used Maven. But its rather obsolete if you have
>> access to a global maven repository.
>>
>> Running the tests I also use Maven, so calling
>> "mvn test" runs all my tests and on the other hand
>> using patterns like "mvn test Dtest=*ServiceTest"
>> runs only the service tests as well.
>>
>> Nevertheless I set the maven install directory
>> to the PATH variable to call it quickly from
>> any project location.
>>
>> Sounds like a promotion for maven, but it really
>> simplifies my tasks.
>>
>> Regards,
>> Martin
